danfulea.math.numerical

Class MinMaxFunc

  • java.lang.Object
    • danfulea.math.numerical.MinMaxFunc

  • public class MinMaxFunc
extends java.lang.Object
    Min. and Max. of functions Based on literature, including Numerical Recipes in C (Cambridge Univ.).
    Author:
    Dan Fulea, 11 OCT. 2006

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void amoeba(double[][] p, double[] y, int ndim, double ftol)
      Multidimensional minimization of the function funk(x) where x[1..ndim] is a vector in ndim dimensions, by the downhill simplex method of Nelder and Mead.
      double amotry(double[][] p, double[] y, double[] psum, int ndim, int ihi, double fac)
      Extrapolates by a factor fac through the face of the simplex across from the high point, tries it, and replaces the high point if the new point is better.
      double brent(double ax, double bx, double cx, double tol)
      Given a function f, and given a bracketing triplet of abscissas ax, bx, cx (such that bx is between ax and cx, and f(bx) is less than both f(ax) and f(cx)), this routine isolates the minimum to a fractional precision of about tol using Brent’s method.
      double brent1(double ax, double bx, double cx, double tol, java.lang.String namS)
      Same as above but this is related to a local function and it is used internally.
      double dbrent(double ax, double bx, double cx, double tol)
      Given a function f and its derivative function df, and given a bracketing triplet of abscissas ax, bx, cx [such that bx is between ax and cx, and f(bx) is less than both f(ax) and f(cx)], this routine isolates the minimum to a fractional precision of about tol using a modification of Brent’s method that uses derivatives.
      double dbrent1(double ax, double bx, double cx, double tol, java.lang.String namS, java.lang.String namS2)
      Same as above but with local functions used internally.
      double df1dim(double x)
      Used internally
      void dfpmin(double[] p, int n, double gtol)
      Given a starting point p[1..n] that is a vector of length n, the Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb- Shanno variant of Davidon-Fletcher-Powell minimization is performed on a function func, using its gradient as calculated by a routine dfunc.
      void dlinmin(double[] p, double[] xi, int n)
      Given an n-dimensional point p[1..n] and an n-dimensional direction xi[1..n], moves and resets p to where the function func(p) takes on a minimum along the direction xi from p, and replaces xi by the actual vector displacement that p was moved.
      private double dlocalFunc(double x, java.lang.String name)
      Local function
      double f1dim(double x)
      Used internally.
      void frprmn(double[] p, int n, double ftol)
      Given a starting point p[1..n], Fletcher-Reeves-Polak-Ribiere minimization is performed on a function func, using its gradient as calculated by a routine dfunc.
      double golden(double ax, double bx, double cx, double tol)
      Given a function f, and given a bracketing triplet of abscissas ax, bx, cx (such that bx is between ax and cx, and f(bx) is less than both f(ax) and f(cx)), this routine performs a golden section search for the minimum, isolating it to a fractional precision of about tol.
      void linmin(double[] p, double[] xi, int n)
      Given an n-dimensional point p[1..n] and an n-dimensional direction xi[1..n], moves and resets p to where the function func(p) takes on a minimum along the direction xi from p, and replaces xi by the actual vector displacement that p was moved.
      void lnsrch(int n, double[] xold, double fold, double[] g, double[] p, double[] x, double stpmax)
      Given an n-dimensional point xold[1..n], the value of the function and gradient there, fold and g[1..n], and a direction p[1..n], finds a new point x[1..n] along the direction p from xold where the function func has decreased “sufficiently.” The new function value is returned in f.
      private double localFunc(double x, java.lang.String name)
      Local function.
      void mnbrak(double ax, double bx)
      Given a function func, and given distinct initial points ax and bx, this routine searches in the downhill direction (defined by the function as evaluated at the initial points) and returns new points ax_mnbrak, bx_mnbrak, cx_mnbrak that bracket a minimum of the function.
      void mnbrak1(double ax, double bx, java.lang.String namS)
      Same as above but this is related to a local function and it is used internally.
      void powell(double[] p, double[][] xi, int n, double ftol)
      Minimization of a function func of n variables.
      static double SIGN(double a, double b)

      • mnbrak

        public void mnbrak(double ax,
                   double bx)
        Given a function func, and given distinct initial points ax and bx, this routine searches in the downhill direction (defined by the function as evaluated at the initial points) and returns new points ax_mnbrak, bx_mnbrak, cx_mnbrak that bracket a minimum of the function. Also returned are the function values at the three points, fa_mnbrak, fb_mnbrak, and fc_mnbrak.
        Parameters:
        ax - ax
        bx - bx

      • mnbrak1

        public void mnbrak1(double ax,
                    double bx,
                    java.lang.String namS)
        Same as above but this is related to a local function and it is used internally.
        Parameters:
        ax - ax
        bx - bx
        namS - the name of local function to be used.

      • golden

        public double golden(double ax,
                     double bx,
                     double cx,
                     double tol)
        Given a function f, and given a bracketing triplet of abscissas ax, bx, cx (such that bx is between ax and cx, and f(bx) is less than both f(ax) and f(cx)), this routine performs a golden section search for the minimum, isolating it to a fractional precision of about tol. The abscissa of the minimum is returned as xmin_golden, and the minimum function value is returned as golden, the returned function value.
        Parameters:
        ax - ax
        bx - bx
        cx - cx
        tol - tol
        Returns:
        the function value

      • brent

        public double brent(double ax,
                    double bx,
                    double cx,
                    double tol)
        Given a function f, and given a bracketing triplet of abscissas ax, bx, cx (such that bx is between ax and cx, and f(bx) is less than both f(ax) and f(cx)), this routine isolates the minimum to a fractional precision of about tol using Brent’s method. The abscissa of the minimum is returned as xmin_brent, and the minimum function value is returned as brent, the returned function value.
        Parameters:
        ax - ax
        bx - bx
        cx - cx
        tol - tol
        Returns:
        the function value

      • dbrent

        public double dbrent(double ax,
                     double bx,
                     double cx,
                     double tol)
        Given a function f and its derivative function df, and given a bracketing triplet of abscissas ax, bx, cx [such that bx is between ax and cx, and f(bx) is less than both f(ax) and f(cx)], this routine isolates the minimum to a fractional precision of about tol using a modification of Brent’s method that uses derivatives. The abscissa of the minimum is returned as xmin_dbrent, and the minimum function value is returned as dbrent, the returned function value.
        Parameters:
        ax - ax
        bx - bx
        cx - cx
        tol - tol
        Returns:
        the function value

      • amoeba

        public void amoeba(double[][] p,
                   double[] y,
                   int ndim,
                   double ftol)
        Multidimensional minimization of the function funk(x) where x[1..ndim] is a vector in ndim dimensions, by the downhill simplex method of Nelder and Mead. The matrix p[1..ndim+1][1..ndim] is input. Its ndim+1 rows are ndim-dimensional vectors which are the vertices of the starting simplex. Also input is the vector y[1..ndim+1], whose components must be preinitialized to the values of funk evaluated at the ndim+1 vertices (rows) of p; and ftol the fractional convergence tolerance to be achieved in the function value. On output, p and y will have been reset to ndim+1 new points all within ftol of a minimum function value, and nfunk gives the number of function evaluations taken.
        Parameters:
        p - p
        y - y
        ndim - ndim
        ftol - ftol

      • amotry

        public double amotry(double[][] p,
                     double[] y,
                     double[] psum,
                     int ndim,
                     int ihi,
                     double fac)
        Extrapolates by a factor fac through the face of the simplex across from the high point, tries it, and replaces the high point if the new point is better. Used internally by amoeba.
        Parameters:
        p - p
        y - y
        psum - psum
        ndim - ndim
        ihi - ihi
        fac - fac
        Returns:
        the result

      • f1dim

        public double f1dim(double x)
        Used internally.
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the result

      • linmin

        public void linmin(double[] p,
                   double[] xi,
                   int n)
        Given an n-dimensional point p[1..n] and an n-dimensional direction xi[1..n], moves and resets p to where the function func(p) takes on a minimum along the direction xi from p, and replaces xi by the actual vector displacement that p was moved. Also returns as fret the value of func at the returned location p. This is actually all accomplished by calling the routines mnbrak and brent.
        Parameters:
        p - p
        xi - xi
        n - n

      • powell

        public void powell(double[] p,
                   double[][] xi,
                   int n,
                   double ftol)
        Minimization of a function func of n variables. Input consists of an initial starting point p[1..n]; an initial matrix xi[1..n][1..n], whose columns contain the initial set of directions (usually the n unit vectors); and ftol, the fractional tolerance in the function value such that failure to decrease by more than this amount on one iteration signals doneness. On output, p is set to the best point found, xi is the then-current direction set, fret is the returned function value at p, and iter is the number of iterations taken. The routine linmin is used.
        Parameters:
        p - p
        xi - xi
        n - n
        ftol - ftol

      • frprmn

        public void frprmn(double[] p,
                   int n,
                   double ftol)
        Given a starting point p[1..n], Fletcher-Reeves-Polak-Ribiere minimization is performed on a function func, using its gradient as calculated by a routine dfunc. The convergence tolerance on the function value is input as ftol. Returned quantities are p (the location of the minimum), iter (the number of iterations that were performed), and fret (the minimum value of the function). The routine linmin is called to perform line minimizations.
        Parameters:
        p - p
        n - n
        ftol - ftol

      • dlinmin

        public void dlinmin(double[] p,
                    double[] xi,
                    int n)
        Given an n-dimensional point p[1..n] and an n-dimensional direction xi[1..n], moves and resets p to where the function func(p) takes on a minimum along the direction xi from p, and replaces xi by the actual vector displacement that p was moved. Also returns as fret the value of func at the returned location p. This is actually all accomplished by calling the routines mnbrak and dbrent.
        Parameters:
        p - p
        xi - xi
        n - n

      • df1dim

        public double df1dim(double x)
        Used internally
        Parameters:
        x - x
        Returns:
        the result

      • lnsrch

        public void lnsrch(int n,
                   double[] xold,
                   double fold,
                   double[] g,
                   double[] p,
                   double[] x,
                   double stpmax)
        Given an n-dimensional point xold[1..n], the value of the function and gradient there, fold and g[1..n], and a direction p[1..n], finds a new point x[1..n] along the direction p from xold where the function func has decreased “sufficiently.” The new function value is returned in f. stpmax is an input quantity that limits the length of the steps so that you do not try to evaluate the function in regions where it is undefined or subject to overflow. p is usually the Newton direction. The output quantity check is false (0) on a normal exit. It is true (1) when x is too close to xold. In a minimization algorithm, this usually signals convergence and can be ignored. However, in a zero-finding algorithm the calling program should check whether the convergence is spurious.
        Parameters:
        n - n
        xold - xold
        fold - fold
        g - g
        p - p
        x - x
        stpmax - stpmax

      • dfpmin

        public void dfpmin(double[] p,
                   int n,
                   double gtol)
        Given a starting point p[1..n] that is a vector of length n, the Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb- Shanno variant of Davidon-Fletcher-Powell minimization is performed on a function func, using its gradient as calculated by a routine dfunc. The convergence requirement on zeroing the gradient is input as gtol. Returned quantities are p[1..n] (the location of the minimum), iter (the number of iterations that were performed), and fret (the minimum value of the function). The routine lnsrch is called to perform approximate line minimizations.
        Parameters:
        p - p
        n - n
        gtol - gtol
